author: Ava
title: Calgarians dig out after spring storm brings over 20 cm of snow
text:
After two days of being under a snowfall warning, Environment and Climate Change Canada (ECCC) said Calgary, Cochrane and parts of central Alberta along the QEII highway were past the worst of the spring snow event Thursday afternoon.
As of 10 a.m. on Thursday, ECCC said Calgary International Airport received 22 centimetres, the most of the seven stations the federal agency reported.
According to Global Calgary chief meteorologist Tiffany Lizee, Calgary has seen 42 centimetres of snow this month, with the normal for March being 23 centimetres.
Calgary police said 104 collisions were reported on Thursday to 4 p.m., including 20 injury collisions, 6 non-injury hit and runs, and two hit and runs that resulted in injuries.
City of Calgary snow crews worked overnight and throughout Thursday to continue to clear the most trafficked roads.
For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/10376363/crews-clear-calgary-roads-snowfall-warning-ends/

author: Agence QMI
title: Itinérance et santé mentale: «Ma mère a presque été dans la rue», confie Bruno Marcil
text:
Itinérance et santé mentale: «Ma mère a presque été dans la rue», confie Bruno Marcil
Personne n'est à l'abri de l'itinérance, a témoigné le comédien Bruno Marcil qui a été marqué par le combat de sa mère contre la schizophrénie.
«Ma mère souffrait d'une forme de schizophrénie. Elle a presque été dans la rue», a raconté la vedette de la quotidienne Stat lors d’une entrevue accordée à QUB radio, au 99,5 FM.
Cette histoire est l'un des facteurs qui l'a motivé à représenter le PAS de la rue, un organisme qui vient en aide aux personnes de 55 ans en situation de grande précarité. L'organisation a d'ailleurs été frappée de plein fouet par la crise de l'itinérance qui ravage tout le Québec.
«Les chiffres sont assez hallucinants parce que la clientèle du PAS de la rue a doublé depuis l'an passé», a-t-il illustré.
«Il manque un investissement à tous les niveaux»
Fasse à la hausse de la demande, de nombreux organismes prendront part à une grande marche du 22 février visant à amasser des fonds pour les aider dans leur lutte contre l'itinérance.
«Il manque un investissement gouvernemental majeur, il manque un investissement à tous les niveaux. Donc, c'est pour ça que je suis là, c'est pour ça qu'on fait cette marche-là et c'est pour ça qu'on invite la population à aider, à venir aussi être bénévole», a rappelé Bruno Marcil.
En effet, la problématique est de plus en plus visible, notamment dans le métro de Montréal, où 60 % des interruptions de service sont liés aux personnes en situation d’itinérance qui sont souvent sous l’emprise de drogue, d’alcool, ou en état de désorganisation, selon des données citées par La Presse.
«Oui, il y a la schizophrénie, la bipolarité. L’alcoolisme fait partie des maladies qui sont très difficiles à gérer pour l’entourage et pour la personne qui en souffre. Et c’est ça qu’on voit dans nos rues, dans les métros, et c’est beaucoup de gens qui souffrent de maladies mentales. Alors, c’est pour ça qu’il faut se mobiliser, il faut faire quelque chose pour aider tout ça», a ajouté le comédien.
Voyez l'entrevue complète dans la vidéo ci-dessus

author: Diana Serbe
title: Traum vom Auswandern zerplatzt: Ex-GZSZ-Star redet Tacheles
text:
Traum vom Auswandern zerplatzt: Ex-GZSZ-Star redet Tacheles
Das Auf und Ab einer Auswanderung erlebte auch eine bekannte Ex-GZSZ-Darstellerin, die ihr Scheitern anfangs als massives Versagen ansah.
Berlin – Auswandern ist für Hunderttausende Deutsche jedes Jahr ein Lebensziel, das sie endlich umsetzen. Darunter sind auch zahlreiche Prominente. Nicht immer verläuft alles wie in der Vorstellung, meist erschweren ungeplante Hürden das Leben in der neuen Heimat. Das musste auch eine Ex-GZSZ-Schauspielerin feststellen. Sie entschied sich dafür, nach Deutschland zurückzukehren.
Ex-GZSZ-Star Isabell Horn unglücklich mit Auswanderung nach Schweden
Für Auswanderer gibt es viele Traumziele. Während es immer mehr Prominente wie Ex-„Tagesschau“-Sprecher Jan Hofer (75) oder „Traumschiff“-Darstellerin Collien Ulmen-Fernandes (43) auf die spanische Insel Mallorca zieht, gibt es für Deutsche noch ein Traumziel im Norden: Schweden. Der Traum von Bullerbü holte auch Ex-GZSZ-Darstellerin Isabell Horn (41) ein. Von 2009 bis 2014 spielte sie in der Vorabend-Telenovela die flippige Pia Koch, die sie auch von 2015 bis 2016 in der RTL-Serie „Alles was zählt“ spielte. Dann wurde es ruhiger um die gebürtige Bielefelderin.
Ihr Buch gibt Aufschluss darüber, warum. In „Bleibt das jetzt so? Die Depression, mein unperfektes Leben und ich“ erzählt sie offen von psychischen Problemen. Ein Leben in einem anderen Land sollte womöglich auch einen Neuanfang für den Kopf bringen. Im Sommer 2023 wanderte die Schauspielerin mit ihrem Partner Jens Ackermann (40) und den gemeinsamen Kindern Ella (8) und Fritz (5) nach Schweden aus. Zunächst hat das Paar wieder mehr zusammengefunden, doch dann bereiteten einige Herausforderungen der Familie Schwierigkeiten.
Ex-GZSZ-Star Isabell Horn hielt Sprachbarriere für großes Problem der Auswanderer
Vor allem die Sprache habe das Sozialleben eingeschränkt. „Ich hatte Hemmungen, konnte mich kaum verständigen“, verriet Isabell Horn gegenüber Closer. „Ich habe mich immer isoliert gefühlt.“ Obwohl Englisch in Schweden weit verbreitet ist, sei es ohne Schwedischkenntnisse schwer, Kontakte zu den Einheimischen zu knüpfen. Einfach mal so ein Plausch im Supermarkt sei nicht möglich gewesen. Auch die Sehnsucht nach Familie und Freunden war groß. Zu RTL sagte die Schauspielerin: „Ich hatte dann auch das Gefühl: Okay, jetzt haben wir hier komplett versagt. Ich wollte nicht so schnell aufgeben.“
Doch der Entschluss stand fest: Die Rückwanderung nach Deutschland sollte nach nur anderthalb Jahren Schweden kommen. Nun ist die Familie zurück in Berlin, was sich „einerseits vertraut, andererseits total fremd“ anfühle, so Horn zu Closer. Den ihren Kindern fehlen der Wald und die Tiere Schwedens, dafür hätten sie ihre alten Freunde in der Schule wieder. Auch Isabells Freundinnen sind nur einen Katzensprung entfernt. Partner Jan pendelte ohnehin nach Berlin für den Job. Auch wenn die Idee für den dauerhaften Wohnsitz vorbei ist, als Urlaubsland soll Schweden der Familie erhalten bleiben.
Mit ihrem Grundstück in Berlin, das sie während der Zeit in Schweden behielten, wollen sie sich bald den Traum vom Eigenheim verwirklichen. Aus der Serien-Familie gibt es weitere glückliche Nachrichten: Ein GZSZ-Darsteller konnte sich trotz Krebs den Traum vom Elterndasein verwirklichen. Verwendete Quellen: rtl.de, „Closer“ (Ausgabe 19/2025)

author: Ev Foley
title: Australian co-developer of PERC solar cells wins prestigious ATSE award
text: [Professor Andrew Blakers](https://www.pv-magazine-australia.com/2024/05/01/no-threat-to-farm-land-just-1200-square-kilometres-can-fulfil-australias-solar-and-wind-energy-needs/) FTSE FAA (ACT) has been recognised for his contribution to the world’s energy transition, named the winner of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering (ATSE) Clunies Ross Technology Innovation Award. Currently an Australian National University (ANU) Professor of Engineering, Blakers helped develop the passivated emitter and rear contact (PERC) solar cells which make up half of all solar cells world-wide and are mitigating an estimated 2% of global greenhouse emissions. He also created a global atlas of about one million possible sites for [off-river pumped hydro](https://www.pv-magazine-australia.com/2024/10/09/energy-storage-is-a-solved-problem/) energy storage with the potential to power about one trillion electric vehicle batteries. “I’ve been working in the area of solar energy and renewable energy since 1979 and I thought then that solar energy would in the end be the major source of energy for the world and this is turned out to be true,” Blakers said. “There’s been continuous rapid exponential growth for 40 or 50 years and our solar is the dominant form of new generation capacity.” Blakers said that it has been shown very large scale and rapid deployment to solar and wind does not lead to technical problems but instead to very low cost, very stable electricity systems. “When we electrify transport, heating and industry we can readily get rid of all fossil fuels over the next 15 years,” he said. During completion of a PhD at the University of New South Wales (NSW) he worked on high efficiency crystalline silicon solar cells and by the time the team had finished [efficiency](https://www.pv-magazine-australia.com/2024/07/29/unsw-team-sheds-new-light-on-solar-cell-efficiency/) had been pushed up to 25%. “The PERC cell design is now in about half all the solar panels ever made. Solar solves energy forever,” he said. PERC solar panel sales to date are approximately $223 billion (USD 150 billion). Blakers and his colleague’s work on the PERC solar cell technology was awarded the top global engineering [Queen Elizabeth Prize](https://www.pv-magazine-australia.com/2023/11/23/perc-inventor-from-unsw-discusses-the-future-of-the-technology/) in 2023, and he is co-inventor of Sliver solar cell technology and, in 1991, founded the ANU solar cell research group. Another ATSE award winner contributing to the energy transition was the Queensland University of Technology (QUT) industrial chemist Professor Sara Couperthwaite for her research in transforming the sustainability of mineral processing and secure critical minerals to power the renewable energy transition. Couperthwaite leads a team that achieved a breakthrough in the production of high purity alumina (HPA), a material that improves the performance and safety of lithium-ion batteries. This content is protected by copyright and may not be reused. If you want to cooperate with us and would like to reuse some of our content, please contact: [editors@pv-magazine.com](/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#86a0a5feb0b3bda0a5feb0b2bda0a5feb0bfbda0a5feb1b2bda0a5feb0e0bda0a5feb1b4bda0a5feb1b5bda0a5feb2b6bda0a5feb1b6bda0a5feb1b0bda0a5feb4e2bda0a5feb0e2bda0a5feb0b7bda0a5feb0b1bda0a5feb0b7bda0a5feb1e7bda0a5feb0bfbda0a5feb0e3bda0a5feb0b3bda0a5feb4e3bda0a5feb0b5bda0a5feb0e0bda0a5feb0e2bd).

author: Samantha House
title: Northern lights shine above Central NY in memorable display (photos) - syracuse.com
text: It has been a big year for the [northern lights](https://www.syracuse.com/weather/2024/09/aurora-awestruck-northern-lights-dance-above-upstate-ny-photos-video.html) in the Empire State. Central New York, however, has mostly been left out of the stunning, celestial party. But last night, it was our turn to see the [aurora borealis](https://www.syracuse.com/state/2024/08/awesome-aurora-see-epic-photos-of-northern-lights-in-upstate-ny.html) in its full, unforgettable glory. The northern lights appeared Thursday in the Syracuse area, starting in the evening before residents turned off their lights and headed to bed. The lights then faded for a few hours before strengthening again shortly before midnight. The aurora arrived as promised after the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Space Weather Prediction Center issued a [severe geometric storm alert](https://www.syracuse.com/outdoors/2024/10/northern-lights-forecast-upgraded-to-severe-could-dazzle-upstate-ny-tonight-or-tomorrow.html) for Oct. 10 and Oct. 11 — delighting Central New Yorkers in Brewerton, Baldwinsville, Pompey, Syracuse and beyond. The generous northern lights didn’t leave the rest of the state out: Photographers across Upstate New York captured stunning shots of the aurora borealis dancing from Geneseo to Seneca Lake and from Niagara Falls to Lake George. While the aurora borealis is forecasted to be visible again in Upstate tonight, the Syracuse area isn’t expected to be included in the encore appearance, according to [NOAA’s aurora forecast](https://www.swpc.noaa.gov/communities/aurora-dashboard-experimental). But sky lovers in the Adirondacks, the North Country and the Niagara Falls area might get lucky. Check out the gorgeous snaps photographers captured of the northern lights dancing above CNY. And keep checking back: We’ll continue to add photos throughout the morning. Did you see the northern lights Thursday in Central New York? Please send your videos and photos to [socialmedia@syracuse.](mailto:socialmedia@syracuse.co)com, including where the image was taken and who the shot should be credited to.

author: Jenny Rocio Angarita
title: “Me siento revictimizada e intimidada”: Génesis Olave García sobre fiscal Mario Burgos
text: “Me siento revictimizada e intimidada”: Génesis Olave García sobre fiscal Mario Burgos Mediante un comunicado, señaló que el fiscal Mario Burgos le dijo que la denunciará y señaló que esto demuestra que el delegado del ente investigador no tiene “objetividad”. Génesis Olave García, la mejor amiga de Laura Ojeda y quien al parecer fue víctima del hackeo de su celular, agenda telefónica y sus redes sociales, por parte de Daysuris del Carmen Vásquez Castro, denunció que se siente “intimidada”, por el fiscal Mario Burgos. Mediante un comunicado emitido en la mañana de este jueves, Olave García confirmó lo que W Radio había informado frente a lo que ocurrió en medio de la imputación de cargos contra Vásquez Castro. “Al finalizar la diligencia, el señor fiscal Mario Andrés Burgos Patiño anunció que formulará denuncia en mi contra por el delito de falsa denuncia, pero que continuará investigando este proceso hasta cuando determine formularla”, relató Olave García. Le puede interesar: Seguidamente agregó que “con el anuncio anterior, me siento revictimizada e intimidada, pues lo último que se espera del desarrollo de una diligencia como estas, es que el fiscal que debe garantizar mis derechos anuncie que quiere convertirme en indiciada en un asunto penal”. Génesis Olave García denunció a finales de 2023 al fiscal Burgos por el delito de prevaricato por omisión, por el poco avance en la investigación a raíz de la violación de sus datos personales, que habría sido ordenada por la exesposa de Nicolás Petro, en su afán de probar la infidelidad con Laura Ojeda. Precisamente, la víctima señaló en esa denuncia que Vásquez Castro habría pagado 20 millones de pesos para hackear su celular y redes sociales. “La actitud asumida por el señor fiscal al finalizar la diligencia denota una falta de objetividad como representante del ente persecutor, pues, teniendo absolutamente claro que va a denunciarme -lo que significa que en su esfera mental soy su contraparte- no se desliga del conocimiento de estos hechos”, aseguró Olave García. Hasta el momento, el fiscal Mario Burgos no se ha pronunciado sobre este episodio que ocurrió en medio de una audiencia reservada que se realizó ante el juez 19 Penal Municipal con Función de Control de Garantías de Bogotá.

author: Redacción
title: Milei confirmó que el Gobierno planea declarar a Hamas como organización terrorista
text: El Gobierno confirmó este sábado que se encuentra “trabajando” para incluir al grupo islamita Hamás en la lista de organizaciones catalogadas como terroristas en Argentina. “Estamos trabajando en eso”, aseguró el presidente Javier Milei en respuesta a un posteo en redes que realizó la diputada de Juntos por el Cambio, Sabrina Ajmechet, donde pedía como “deseo de navidad” que la organización islamista ocupe un lugar en ese listado. De este modo, Milei hizo publica su intención de incorporar a Hamás y el brazo militar, las Brigadas de Ezzeldin AlQassam, al Registro Público de Personas y Entidades vinculadas a actos de Terrorismo y su Financiamiento. En noviembre pasado, el actual mandatario y su vicepresidenta Victoria Villarruel le habían solicitado lo propio en calidad de diputados al por entonces presidente Alberto Fernández. A través de un proyecto que presentó junto a 22 integrantes del bloque PRO, encabezados por Cristian Ritondo, el presidente había pedido además que el gobierno "disponga el congelamiento de activos de todos los jefes y cabecillas de la organización". En tanto, Ajmechet es una de las legisladoras de JxC que viene respaldando fuertemente el DNU que presentó el presidente y los cambios urgentes que propone el nuevo gobierno. Además, la diputada cuestionó a quienes critican las políticas de shock que está implementando el jefe de Estado. “Me parece una vergüenza que tantas personas que se mantuvieron absolutamente calladas durante cuatro años durante el gobierno de Alberto Fernández, que tantos derechos individuales cercenó mediante DNUs durante la pandemia y nadie dijo nada, ahora pongan piedras en el camino y empiecen a plantear que este Gobierno tiene que caer”, consideró Ajmechet en declaraciones a Noticias Argentinas. En este sentido, la diputada manifestó: "Esas expresiones me parecen antidemocráticas e irresponsables. Es imprescindible que se respete la voluntad popular. Apenas transcurrieron días del nuevo Gobierno y los cambios que está impulsado Milei son los que prometió en la campaña". Con información de NA

author: #ThisIsTucson staff
title: 34 fun events happening in Tucson this weekend Jan. 11-14
text:
After a cold week and a dash of
snow, it looks like the weekend is set to bring a little bit of warmth and sunshine to Tucson.
Here's what's going on: the Tucson Jazz Festival kicks off and the Zoppé Circus is back in town. Celebrate Japanese New Year at Yume Japanese Gardens, sing along to all your Bowie favorites at Surly Wench and explore the Tucson Museum of Art for pay-what-you-wish admission.
Of course, things can change quickly these days. Check for the latest info before heading out!
Zoppé Family Circus
Zoppé Family Circus, featuring Nino the Clown and a cast of seven generations of Zoppés, is back in Tucson this winter. Expect acrobatic acts, a trapeze artist, a ringmaster and more. The circus has been a January tradition in Tucson since 2011.
People are also reading…
When: Now through Jan. 21
Where: Mercado District,
100 S. Avenida del Convento
Cost: $25 for general admission, $45 for ringside
Discovery Nights at Children's Museum Tucson
Visit Children's Museum Tucson for a free night of science and art, including story times and pop-up science experiments.
When: 5-7 p.m. Thursdays
Where: Children's Museum Tucson,
200 S. Sixth Ave.
Cost: Free to attend
Unbox a brighter future with Girl Scout Cookies!
The future is sweet, and it's in your hands! Every bite of
Girl Scout Cookies is a bite towards real change in our communities and beyond. Unbox the future by supporting your local Girl Scout entrepreneurs.
Art Corner with BICAS
Get free access to recycled bike art parts, tools and other materials and get creative! Once you're finished, you can donate your creation to BICAS or give a suggested donation to the nonprofit, if you're able to. Check in at the front counter before heading to the art area.
When: 3-6 p.m. Thursdays
Where: BICAS,
2001 N. Seventh Ave.
Cost: Free to attend, donation suggested
Gather A Vintage Market
Find all kinds of vintage and antique home and garden items at this four-day market.
When: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Thursday-Saturday, Jan. 11-13; 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 14
Where: Gather A Vintage Market,
300 S. Park Ave.
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
ATC presents “Intimate Apparel” Jan. 20-Feb. 10
The
Arizona Theatre Company presents the two-time Pulitzer Prize-winning author Lynn Nottage’s play “ Intimate Apparel.” The story features a successful seamstress who makes revolutionary undergarments for an array of women, exploring forbidden relationships and clientele that profoundly change her life. Get tickets now!
Tucson International Jewish Film Festival
From Jan. 11-31, dozens of films will be screened as part of the Tucson International Jewish Film Festival. Some films will be screened in person throughout the Tucson area. Others will be available to screen virtually.
When: Jan. 11-31
Where: Several locations
Cost: $60 for six films, $135 for all films
Libra & Thorn Workshops
Metaphysical art shop Libra & Thorn is hosting two workshops this weekend: manifestation candles on Thursday and books of shadows on Saturday.
When: 2 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 11 for candles; 6-8 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13 for book of shadows.
Where: Libra & Thorn,
101 S. Pantano Road
Cost: $25 for candles; $30 for book of shadows
Local Love Series at Hotel McCoy
Celebrating local music and vendors, Hotel McCoy is hosting a free poolside concert with folk musician Jacob Acosta alongside artist Qmulative, who creates Arizona-themed pocket tees.
When: 6-8 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 11
Where: Hotel McCoy,
720 W. Silverlake Road
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Tucson Jazz Festival
January in Tucson means jazz. The theme for this year's HSL Properties Tucson Jazz Festival is "Join the Party." Expect musicians like Arturo Sandoval, Trombone Shorty and Calexico.
When: Jan. 12-20
Where: Several locations
Cost: Varies. A free fiesta takes place Jan. 15.
Tasting History: Herbs
Learn about the origins behind herbs like lemongrass and cilantro and how they became part of Tucson's agricultural and culinary traditions. Demonstrations and tastings are part of the fun.
When: 9-11 a.m. Friday-Saturday, Jan. 12-13
Where: Mission Garden,
946 W. Mission Lane
Cost: Free to attend, donations accepted
Crafting with This n' That Creative Studio
This n' That Creative Studio is hosting two crafty events this Friday. The first, on Friday morning, is a story time event featuring "Be Brave, Little Penguin." After story time is over, kids will get to participate in a craft related to the book. On Friday evening, make a stack of Valentine's Day bracelets.
When: 10 a.m. Friday, Jan. 12 for story time; 6 p.m. Friday, Jan. 12 for bracelets
Where: This n' That Creative Studio,
1066 S. Pantano Road
Cost: $10 for story time, $35 for bracelets
Magic & Mystery Dinner Theater
At this event, you'll get to enjoy dinner from Dante's Fire, all while watching a magical theatrical performance.
When: 6:30 p.m. Friday, Jan. 12
Where: Dante's Fire,
2526 E. Grant Road
Cost: $49 without dinner, $79 with dinner
Cat events at El Jefe Cat Cafe
Spend time with the cats at El Jefe Cat Cafe! This weekend's events include sound bath meditation and cat bingo.
When: 7-8 p.m. Friday, Jan. 12 for sound bath; 6-7 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 14 for bingo
Where: El Jefe Cat Cafe,
3025 N. Campbell Ave.
Cost: $25 for sound bath; $14 for bingo, reservations required
Rockin' Minerals
Shop minerals, fossils and jewelry alongside hands-on geology activities for kids at the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum.
When: 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday-Sunday, Jan. 13-14
Where: Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum,
2021 N. Kinney Road
Cost: Museum admission is $29.95 for adults ages 13 and up ($24.95 for Arizona and Sonora residents). Kids ages 3-12 get in for $19.95.
Japanese New Year Festival 2024
Celebrate the Year of the Dragon at Yume Japanese Gardens of Tucson. Watch live performances, enjoy Japanese food and see the annual mochitsuki ritual, which is the pounding of rice to make mochi.
When: 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Yume Japanese Gardens of Tucson,
2130 N. Alvernon Way
Cost: $18 for adults, $6 for kids. Advanced registration is required.
Sahuarita Art on the Lake Festival
Experience art in Sahuarita! You'll have the chance to shop local artwork and enjoy interactive art activities, such as a community chalk mural competition. There will also be live music and food trucks.
When: 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Sahuarita Lake Park,
15466 S. Rancho Sahuarita Blvd.
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping and food
Bowie Tribute at Surly Wench
Surly Wench Pub is hosting a Bowie tribute this weekend, featuring performers, giveaways and a vendor selling dark jewelry.
When: 9 p.m. to 2 a.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Surly Wench Pub,
424 N. Fourth Ave.
Cost: $5
Art After Dark at Children's Museum Tucson
Each month, Children's Museum Tucson hosts Art After Dark with local arts groups and free admission! The star of this week's Art After Dark is KXCI, who will spin playlists created by youth DJs.
When: 5:30-7:30 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Children's Museum Tucson,
200 S. Sixth Ave.
Cost: Free to attend
Tucson Repair Cafe
Need something fixed? Bring it to the Tucson Repair Cafe to be fixed for free! All items are welcome.
When: 4-8 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Xerocraft Makerspace,
101 W. Sixth St.
Cost: Free to attend
2nd Saturdays
Check out food trucks, live music and local makers during this monthly outdoor street festival.
When: 5-10 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Downtown Tucson along
East Congress Street
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping and food
Second Saturday at Steam Pump Ranch
The second Saturday of every month is special at Steam Pump Ranch. Find historic tours of the grounds, demonstrations led by Archaeology Southwest, crafts for kids, vendors selling their artwork and a farmers market.
When: 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Steam Pump Ranch,
10901 N. Oracle Road
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Stargazing with Tucson Amateur Astronomy Association
Go stargazing with Tucson Amateur Astronomy Association at Agua Caliente Park! The group will have several telescopes available.
When: 6:30-8:30 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Agua Caliente Park,
12325 E. Roger Road
Cost: Free to attend, registration required
Di Luna x Barista del Barrio Workshop
Head to Barista del Barrio for a workshop in collaboration with Di Luna Candles where you'll make a 16-inch mosaic saguaro. You'll also get a Barista del Barrio tumbler and a hot chocolate or latte alongside the craft.
When: 12:30 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Barista del Barrio,
1002 N. Grande Ave.
Cost: $60
Silent Adventures
Silent disco meets flash mob with Silent Adventures! Put on your headphones and dance your way through downtown Tucson.
When: 3:30 p.m. Saturdays, Jan. 13-20
Where: Joel D. Valdez Main Library,
101 N. Stone Ave.
Cost: $25 for adults, $15 for kids
Three Artist Photography Exhibit
This Saturday marks opening night for Decode Gallery's next exhibit, which features three photo projects.
When: 5-8 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Decode Gallery,
314 S. Convent Ave.
Cost: Free to attend
Living History Day
Head to Living History Day at the Presidio Museum to learn about the types of jobs people had in the 18th and 19th centuries. There will be demonstrations like blacksmithing and soldier drills, plus music and tortilla tastings.
When: 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Presidio San Agustín del Tucson Museum,
196 N. Court Ave.
Cost: $9 for adults, $6 for kids ages 6-13
Bachata Social Dance Night
Put on your dancing shoes for a night of music and mingling! Enjoy a bachata class followed by social dancing.
When: 8 p.m. to midnight Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Tucson Creative Dance Center,
3131 N. Cherry Ave.
Cost: $15, cash or Venmo
St. Philip's Plaza Market
Visit St. Philip's Plaza to shop from local makers from silversmiths to candle makers.
When: 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturdays and Sundays
Where: St. Philip's Plaza,
4280 N. Campbell Ave.
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping and food
Foothills Community Markets
Visit this market at the Foothills Mall to shop from vendors who have items like yard art, home decor, jewelry, baked goods and more.
When: 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Foothills Mall,
7325 N. La Cholla Blvd.
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Visit the
website for more information.
Walking tours with the Presidio Museum
Explore Tucson with walking tours hosted by the Presidio Museum. This weekend, take a tour of the Turquoise Trail, where you'll see historic buildings and learn Tucson history.
When: 10 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Presidio San Agustín del Tucson Museum,
https://www.google.com/maps/place/Presidio+San+Agust%C3%ADn+del+Tucson+Museum/@32.224195,-110.9737738,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x399d152bfc2ed526?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwini5yf8c6DAxUqJ0QIHYAlBGoQ_BJ6BAguEAA
Cost: $30. Pre-registration is required.
Goat yoga
Enjoy an hour of yoga and goats with this class at Udall Park!
When: 9-10 a.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Northeast of the Udall Pool building at Udall Park,
7290 E. Tanque Verde Road
Cost: $25
Second SundAZe at TMA
Visit the Tucson Museum of Art every second Sunday for pay-what-you-wish admission. Enjoy art-making, gallery activities, family yoga and a performance by AZ Peruvian.
When: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 14
Where: Tucson Museum of Art,
140 N. Main Ave.
Cost: Pay what you wish
Mercado Flea
Check out more than 45 vendors selling antique and vintage items at the Mercado Flea.
When: 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. on the second Sunday of each month through May.
Where: Mercado District,
https://www.google.com/maps/place/Mercado+San+Agustin/@32.2201355,-110.9856285,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x40b972c33497401f?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjtje746aT6AhXFKkQIHdF8CdUQ_BJ6BAhdEAU
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Rodeo Parade Barn Dance at The Maverick
The Tucson Rodeo Parade and Museum is hosting a barn dance fundraiser at The Maverick. Expect live music and dance lessons.
When: 4 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 14
Where: The Maverick,
6622 E. Tanque Verde Road
Cost: $10 in advance, $15 at the door
Chez Peachy Bento Cake Workshop
Chez Peachy is known for her colorful lunchbox-size cakes. Come Sunday, she'll teach you how to decorate your own cake to take home.
When: 4-6 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 14
Where: The Monica,
40 E. Congress St.
Cost: $50
